Messages.Author: Christy Rebecca Kulz
Messages.Content: Hello Everyone, Our seminar on Thursday will now take place in MAR 0.017 rather than the old room. Apologies for the continual changes, but there was a shortage for this timeframe, so I am taking whichever nicer rooms happen to come available. Please have a look at the Hartman text, as well as the City as an Archive text if you have time. Also, I would be very grateful if you could fill out the course evaluation if possible. It is really helpful for my development as a seminar leader; the link is located here: https://befragung.tu-berlin.de/evasys/online.php?p=HLJP9. Thank you in advance for your feedback!  I look forward to seeing you tomorrow for our last official seminar. I will, however, keep our time slot free on July 18th from 10-12. I will be in my office in FH 824 in case you would like to come by and discuss your essay or if you have other questions during this time.  All best wishes, Christy

Messages.Author: Christy Rebecca Kulz
Messages.Content: Hello everyone,  I wanted to remind everyone that our seminar this Thursday will return to the large institut raum in FH804 in Fraunhoferstrasse 33-36.  I also have added a complimentary, more European-focussed text as a counterpoint to McKittrick's more US-based focus on the black diasporic experience. Please read this if you can as well. I would also like to return to the Roy text briefly next week, as we did not have time to discuss that last week.  I wish you a good start in the week and look forward to seeing you all on Thursday!  All best,  Christy

Messages.Author: Christy Rebecca Kulz
Messages.Content: Hello everyone,  Our session presenters for this coming Thursday morning, Ada and Consuelo, have proposed that we move our session to the green space behind the middle of the TU campus, between the back side of the building and the TU main building. They have kindly shared a map indicating the location (see red dot). If it is scheduled to rain, I will send an email late Wed eve or early Thursday and we can revert to the windowless classroom. All best wishes, and I look forward to seeing you on Thursday.  Christy

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Workshop with Prof Nikki Jones on Police Abolition, 8 May 3pm

Messages.Author: Christy Rebecca Kulz
Messages.Content: Hello Everyone,  I just wanted to share this event on police reform and abolition that might be of interest to some of you. It takes place at the SFB 1265 next Wednesday 8th May at 3pm.  All best,  Christy  Workshop “Brutal & Routine” w/ Nikki Jones SFB 1265 8. May 15:00 – 18:00 Uhr  Program “Brutal & Routine: Why Police Reform Always Fails and Why We Need Abolition” Nikki Jones (UC Berkeley) will share some of her work from her current book project, BRUTAL AND ROUTINE, to be published by W.W. Norton Press. The book draws on 20 years of research to crystallize a new and necessary understanding of police violence, with a reasoned argument for the limits of reform and the potential for abolition. The presentation will be followed by an extended commentary by Christy Kulz (TU Berlin), drawing on her own research on the racialization and criminalization of young people in British schools Venue: TU Berlin | BH-N 230, Ernst-Reuter-Platz 1 Berlin, 10587 Deutschland Contact: SFB 1265 info@sfb1265.tu-berlin.de  https://sfb1265.de/en/events/workshop-brutal-routine/

Messages.Author: Christy Rebecca Kulz
Messages.Content: Hello Everyone,  Please find the schedule for presentations/discussion leading for our seminar. If you are not yet signed up, look at the slots with less than 3 presenters and email me with which week you would like to join. I will do my best to accommodate your request, but we may have to assign some weeks so that there is a balance. It works well if you work together with your colleagues on your shared week, so please also get in touch with your fellow students.  Thank you and have a good weekend! Christy Kulz  May 2nd - ‘Imperial Intimacies’ - Paula, Sima, Zorah  May 9 – No Class - Christi Himmelfahrt  May 16 - Struggles for Recognition – Simton, Lukas  May 23rd - Hierarchies of Belonging and Intersectionality – Consuelo, Araneda, Ada  May 30th - Shades of Whiteness – Katharina   June 6th - Bodies out of place - Püren  June 13th - ‘Queer Regenerations’ – Valerija, Erika, Andrea  June 20th - Practices of Urban Homemaking – Mersede, Farzaneh, Viviana  June 27th - Neoliberal capitalism, racial capitalism and subjects of value - Gesa  July 4th - A sense of place in colonisation’s wake - Yuliya  July 11th - Constructing new narratives / re-interpreting the archive – Bahare, Setareh, Reihane  July 18th - Review
